Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A critical bearing is screeching loudly and threatening an immediate breakdown.
Story: I was halfway through my lunch when the building manager called, asking me to check a machine in the basement. The bearing was screeching so loudly it echoed up the stairwell, and I knew if I didn’t fix it soon, the whole system could fail. I grabbed my tools and rushed out, only to run into Mrs. Kim and a few other neighbors in the lobby. They were gathered for a meeting about the recent noise complaints—ironically, probably about the very machine I was supposed to fix. Mrs. Kim smiled and greeted me, expecting the usual friendly chat. I could see the expectation in her eyes: be polite, listen, maybe even apologize on behalf of the building. But my mind was racing with the urgency of the repair. Every second I spent here, the risk of a breakdown grew. I felt torn, caught between being the considerate neighbor everyone expected and the responsible repairer who needed to act fast. My heart pounded as I stood there, tools in hand, unsure which role to fulfill first.
